column5: Yes! Itâ€™s often easier to just do the task yourself at a certain point, rather than asking someone repeatedly when they are going to get around to it. Especially when the answer is â€œin a minuteâ€ or something like that, but the â€œminuteâ€ never comes. So you stop asking and do the task yourself but that doesnâ€™t mean youâ€™re happy about it. In cases like these, if your wife â€œwonâ€™t say whatâ€™s wrongâ€ itâ€™s because sheâ€™s already told you a thousand times and is sick of repeating herself. So if you often rely on your wife to tell you how to help with this and then also rely on her to explain to you why sheâ€™s angry you didnâ€™t, youâ€™re headed for divorce and itâ€™s your own fault.

Oh totally. Back when I was just suspicious of everything I totally identified as a skeptic so I know how people can misuse the word. I think I was still, in a sense, I just wasnâ€™t always applying it to every belief uniformly. It helped to learn about the laws of logic and what logical fallacies were also. I think that should be taught early in schools, itâ€™s pretty crucial for understanding why itâ€™s logical to reach one conclusion over another, rather than what â€œmakes sense to meâ€.

Back when I was still in it, I ran into a lot of people whoâ€™d criticize me for not vaccinating but when you asked just a few simple questions, it was clear they didnâ€™t know what they were talking about. They were right, yes. But they didnâ€™t know why they were right and they were SO SURE about it. That kind of thing kept me stuck in my wrong mindset for awhile. Moral of the story: If you (general â€œyouâ€) donâ€™t fully understand something, donâ€™t try to debate the other side. Theyâ€™ll dig their heels in when they feel theyâ€™ve won the argument. Better just to make the information accessible and as easy to understand as possible. And to teach people how to think instead of what to think.

There is certainly a lot of criticism that can be thrown at many aspects of western medicine and the way itâ€™s practiced.

Itâ€™s a pretty varied group, lots of different backgrounds. I would say a large amount of the husbands I encountered were convinced and agreed for religious reasons or they just didnâ€™t care to look into it one way or the other. Kind of like â€œMy wife feels really strongly about this so Iâ€™ll just go along with whatever she says.â€

Good question. I like to believe- yes, I would have found my way out eventually. As I got older, I became less and less sure I was correct, which I think itâ€™s most peopleâ€™s experience. Since my beliefs were largely based off fear, I wasnâ€™t all that committed to any particular dogma, if that makes sense. I wasnâ€™t committed to it as a â€œcauseâ€. I was never a Wakefield fan- I never believed vaccines caused autism or anything like that. It was all â€œbut WHAT IF...â€ kind of things. I worried about cancer and autoimmune disease, etc. What if GMOs are changing us on a genetic level?? I dunno, itâ€™s hard to put myself back in that mindset, it all seems so ridiculous now. 

The flat earth and other conspiracies were a wake up call I couldnâ€™t ignore but I think as other people became more aware and pushed back against anti-vaxxers, the correct information would have been impossible for me to avoid for much longer.
Dude. Donâ€™t even get me started on essential oils. Iâ€™m gonna rage flip my furniture over here.

Oh totally, I 100% agree. Itâ€™s all a balance really. Thereâ€™s a time and a place for some natural medicine, itâ€™s for minor stuff- not emergencies or when someoneâ€™s life is at stake when there is a perfectly valid medical standard available. 

But even the â€œharmlessâ€ stuff should be examined critically. Giving your kid homeopathic teething remedies may give the appearance being a solution and not causing any actual harm, but the companies who manufacture this crap are often predatory and unregulated. It contributes to the overall idea that â€œnatural is betterâ€, which Iâ€™d love for everyone to unlearn.
Home visits and help with breastfeeding?? Thatâ€™s like a dream.

I actually donâ€™t necessarily count homebirth as â€œcrunchyâ€, at least not when itâ€™s not seen as some ultimate goal and test of your womanhood as it is in these circles. Plenty of countries have practices like what youâ€™ve described and itâ€™s been proven to work. Like I mentioned before, the unnecessary and harmful interventions that became routine in the US for pregnancy and childbirth is what Iâ€™d consider a leading factor into mothers not trusting the medical community in general. The US is pretty far down the list when it comes to things like maternal and child mortality rates, weâ€™re not doing so well. So in that sense, theyâ€™re right to question â€œthe systemâ€, they just take it too far in the opposite direction. Just because something is natural, doesnâ€™t mean itâ€™s better and the same is true for the opposite as well. Thereâ€™s always some truth in the lie, ya know.

I think a major flaw in human logic plays a part and thatâ€™s that itâ€™s counter intuitive to most people to understand that your own experiences arenâ€™t valid when considering information on a larger scale. Just because something â€œworked for youâ€ doesnâ€™t mean thatâ€™s the right course of action. We have scientific studies we can refer to to see how something will affect most people over longer periods of time but most of our human learning experience throughout our lives involve cause and effect on a personal level like, â€œtouch the stove- itâ€™s hot- donâ€™t do it againâ€. So as far as how our brains work, it seems to make sense that if you give your kid vitamin C while they have a cold and they get better, youâ€™ve done the correct thing. It takes more brain work and effort to understand why thatâ€™s not how any of this works.

Iâ€™ve always been a skeptic, I just didnâ€™t have all the right information. I think the question is, what led me to believe that crap in the first place. I think thereâ€™s a real and clear history of western medicine fucking up when it comes to womenâ€™s health so that plus my misguided attempts to follow my own motherly instincts (read: completely and total fear) and my age (19 when I gave birth) it was easy for me to get sucked into a community of â€œexperiencedâ€ parents who seemed to have figured out a better way to raise children. I very much fell for the whole â€œnatural is good/chemicals are badâ€ hype, it took a better understanding of chemistry to pull me out of that. What really made me hop off the train entirely was when I noticed that anti-vax/natural medicine  ways of thinking were correlated to other conspiracies, like flat earth. That was the eye-opener that made me run the other way and start actually looking into everything.

This is especially horrifying to me because of how easily it could have been me/my child back when I was on that granola-mom train. I feel incredibly lucky nothing like this ever happened to her.
